Rotations as a Special Case of Vector Transformations

Rotations, as a class of linear vector transformations1, represent rigid body transformations that change the direction of a vector within a given plane.
Efficient and accurate handling of such transformations poses challenges not only for game and animation engines, but also for simulations and real-time systems, where the limitations of floating-point arithmetic and operation throughput can negatively impact the computational outcomes ([ğŸ“–She97], [ğŸ“–Kui99]).

This work introduces vector rotation with a focus on the relations between its two- and three-dimensional formulations.

We begin in the two-dimensional plane by deriving classical rotation matrices from linear combinations in orthogonal bases.

We then generalize this approach by introducing Rodrigues' rotation formula, which provides a compact expression for rotation around arbitrary axes in three-dimensional space. We verify that the standard rotation matrices emerge as special cases from this general form.

Finally, we illustrate the application of vector rotation in the context of embedded coordinate systems within large scene graphs, demonstrating how transformations propagate across hierarchical structures in real-time environments such as video games.

Vector Rotation as a Linear Combinationâ€‹

Given an angle Î˜\ThetaÎ˜ and an orthonormal basis in three-dimensional space, rotating a vector vâƒ—\vec{v}v around one of the cardinal axes can be computed with a rotation matrix R(Î˜)\boldsymbol{R}(\Theta)R(Î˜).

The following matrices define rotations about the xxx, yyy and zzz axes, respectively:

Rx(Î˜)=(1000cosâ¡Î˜âˆ’sinâ¡Î˜0sinâ¡Î˜cosâ¡Î˜)\boldsymbol{R}_x(\Theta) = \begin{pmatrix} &1 &0 &0 \\ &0 &\cos \Theta &-\sin \Theta\\ &0 &\sin \Theta &\cos \Theta \end{pmatrix}Rxâ€‹(Î˜)=â€‹â€‹100â€‹0cosÎ˜sinÎ˜â€‹0âˆ’sinÎ˜cosÎ˜â€‹â€‹ Ry(Î˜)=(cosâ¡Î˜0sinâ¡Î˜010âˆ’sinâ¡Î˜0cosâ¡Î˜)\boldsymbol{R}_y(\Theta) = \begin{pmatrix} &\cos \Theta & 0 &\sin \Theta\\ &0 &1 &0\\ &-\sin \Theta & 0 &\cos \Theta \end{pmatrix}Ryâ€‹(Î˜)=â€‹â€‹cosÎ˜0âˆ’sinÎ˜â€‹010â€‹sinÎ˜0cosÎ˜â€‹â€‹ Rz(Î˜)=(cosâ¡Î˜âˆ’sinâ¡Î˜0sinâ¡Î˜cosâ¡Î˜0001)\boldsymbol{R}_z(\Theta) = \begin{pmatrix} &\cos \Theta &-\sin \Theta &0\\ &\sin \Theta &\cos \Theta &0\\ &0 &0 &1 \end{pmatrix}Rzâ€‹(Î˜)=â€‹â€‹cosÎ˜sinÎ˜0â€‹âˆ’sinÎ˜cosÎ˜0â€‹001â€‹â€‹

The matrix Rz\boldsymbol{R}_zRzâ€‹ directly arises from rotating a vector in the two-dimensional xyxyxy-plane. This connection will be established in the following.

In an orthonormal basis with the standard basis vectors xâƒ—=(10)\vec{x} = \begin{pmatrix} 1\\0\end{pmatrix}x=(10â€‹), yâƒ—=(01)\vec{y} = \begin{pmatrix} 0\\1\end{pmatrix}yâ€‹=(01â€‹), any vector of unit length can be expressed as

vâƒ—=(cosâ¡Î˜sinâ¡Î˜)\vec{v} = \begin{pmatrix} \cos \Theta \\ \sin \Theta \end{pmatrix}v=(cosÎ˜sinÎ˜â€‹)

This follows directly by cosâ¡Î˜,sinâ¡Î˜\cos \Theta, \sin \ThetacosÎ˜,sinÎ˜ when writing vâƒ—\vec{v}v as a linear combination of the two linear independent vectors xâƒ—,yâƒ—\vec{x}, \vec{y}x,yâ€‹:

vâƒ—=axâƒ—+byâƒ—\vec{v} = a \vec{x} + b \vec{y}v=ax+byâ€‹

Substituting a,ba, ba,b with cosâ¡Î˜\cos \ThetacosÎ˜, sinâ¡Î˜\sin \ThetasinÎ˜, we have:

vâƒ—=cosâ¡Î˜(10)+sinâ¡Î˜(01)=(cosâ¡Î˜sinâ¡Î˜)\vec{v} = \cos \Theta \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} + \sin \Theta \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \cos \Theta \\ \sin \Theta \end{pmatrix}v=cosÎ˜(10â€‹)+sinÎ˜(01â€‹)=(cosÎ˜sinÎ˜â€‹)

or, as a matrix multiplication

(1001)(cosâ¡Î˜sinâ¡Î˜)=vâƒ—\begin{pmatrix} 1 &0 \\ 0 &1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \cos \Theta \\\sin \Theta \end{pmatrix} = \vec{v}(10â€‹01â€‹)(cosÎ˜sinÎ˜â€‹)=v

(Observe how xâƒ—,yâƒ—\vec{x}, \vec{y}x,yâ€‹ represent the identity matrix I2I_{2}I2â€‹).

In Figure 1, the angle Î˜\ThetaÎ˜ represents the amount of rotation of vâƒ—\vec{v}v around the origin2.

Figure 1 The vector v is rotated around the origin by Î¸ degree, resulting in vector v'.
Plot-Code (Python)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from matplotlib.patches import Arc, FancyArrowPatch

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(6, 6))

# Plot setup
ax.set_xlim(-1.1, 1.1)
ax.set_ylim(-1.1, 1.1)
ax.set_xticks([-1, 0, 1])
ax.set_yticks([-1, 0, 1])
ax.set_aspect('equal')
ax.grid(True, linestyle=':', linewidth=0.5)

for spine in ax.spines.values():
    spine.set_visible(False)

ax.spines['bottom'].set_position('zero')
ax.spines['left'].set_position('zero')
ax.spines['bottom'].set_visible(True)
ax.spines['left'].set_visible(True)

ax.xaxis.set_ticks_position('bottom')
ax.yaxis.set_ticks_position('left')

ax.text(1.05, 0.02, r"$x$", fontsize=14, va='bottom')
ax.text(0.02, 1.05, r"$y$", fontsize=14, ha='left')

# Vecors
origin = np.array([0, 0])
theta = np.radians(45)
cos_theta = np.cos(theta)
sin_theta = np.sin(theta)
opposite = np.array([0, np.sin(theta)])
v1 = np.array([np.cos(theta), np.sin(theta)])
v2 = np.array([1, 0])

ax.quiver(*origin, *v1, angles='xy', scale_units='xy', scale=1,  color='r')
ax.quiver(*origin, *v2, angles='xy', scale_units='xy', scale=1, alpha = 0.5, color='r')

offset = 0.01
ax.text(v1[0] - 0.5, v1[1] -0.3, r"$\vec{v'}$", fontsize=12, color='r')
ax.text(v2[0] - 0.2, v2[1]  -0.12, r"$\vec{v}$", fontsize=12, color='r')

# COSINE
ax.plot([0, cos_theta], [-0.02, -0.02], color='black', linestyle='--', linewidth=1)
ax.text(cos_theta / 2 - 0.05, -0.1, r"$\cos(\Theta)$", fontsize=10)

# SINE
start = np.array([cos_theta, 0])
end = start + opposite
ax.plot([start[0], end[0]], [start[1], end[1]], color='black', linewidth=1, linestyle='--')
ax.text(cos_theta + 0.05, sin_theta / 2 - 0.05, r"$\sin(\Theta)$", fontsize=10)


# Unit Circle
circle = plt.Circle((0, 0), 1, color='black', linewidth=0.2, fill=False, transform=ax.transData, linestyle='--')
ax.add_patch(circle)

arrow = FancyArrowPatch(
    posA=(0.5, 0),
    posB=(np.cos(theta)*0.5, np.sin(theta)*0.51),
    connectionstyle="arc3,rad=0.2",
    arrowstyle='->',
    color='blue',
    linestyle='--',
    mutation_scale=15,
    lw=1.5
)
ax.add_patch(arrow)
ax.text(0.5, 0.2, r"$\Theta$", color='blue', fontsize=16)

plt.show()

We claim that

vâƒ—=axâƒ—+byâƒ—\vec{v} = a \vec{x} + b \vec{y}v=ax+byâ€‹

holds for any orthonormal basis, not necessarily the standard basis (which turns out to be just a special case once we have proven the claim).

We require a2+b2=1\sqrt{a^2 + b^2} = 1a2+b2â€‹=1 to ensure that vâƒ—\vec{v}v has unit length. This condition is immediately satisfied by choosing a=cosâ¡Î˜,b=sinâ¡Î˜a=\cos \Theta, b = \sin \Thetaa=cosÎ˜,b=sinÎ˜, as derived in the following proof.

Expressing the linear combination with cosine and sineâ€‹

Let xâƒ—,yâƒ—âˆˆR2\vec{x}, \vec{y} \in \mathbb{R}^2x,yâ€‹âˆˆR2, xâƒ—â‹…yâƒ—=0\vec{x} \cdot \vec{y} = 0xâ‹…yâ€‹=0, âˆ£xâƒ—âˆ£=âˆ£yâƒ—âˆ£=1|\vec{x}| = |\vec{y}| = 1âˆ£xâˆ£=âˆ£yâ€‹âˆ£=1, a,bâˆˆR[0,1]a, b \in \mathbb{R}_{[0, 1]}a,bâˆˆR[0,1]â€‹, a2+b2=1a^2 + b ^2 = 1a2+b2=1.

Claim: The linear combination axâƒ—+byâƒ—a\vec{x} + b\vec{y}ax+byâ€‹ can be written as cosâ¡(Î˜)xâƒ—+sinâ¡(Î˜)yâƒ—\cos(\Theta)\vec{x} + \sin(\Theta)\vec{y}cos(Î˜)x+sin(Î˜)yâ€‹ and yields a normalized vector vâƒ—\vec{v}v:

v^=cosâ¡(Î˜)xâƒ—+sinâ¡(Î˜)yâƒ—\hat{v} = \cos(\Theta)\vec{x} + \sin(\Theta)\vec{y}v^=cos(Î˜)x+sin(Î˜)yâ€‹

Proof:

We compute the dot products vâƒ—â‹…xâƒ—\vec{v} \cdot \vec{x}vâ‹…x, vâƒ—â‹…yâƒ—\vec{v} \cdot \vec{y}vâ‹…yâ€‹ to relate the cosines of the angles Î˜\ThetaÎ˜ (between xâƒ—\vec{x}x and vâƒ—\vec{v}v) and Ï†\varphiÏ† (between yâƒ—\vec{y}yâ€‹ and vâƒ—\vec{v}v), respectively:

vâƒ—â‹…xâƒ—=cosâ¡(Î˜)âˆ£vâƒ—âˆ£âˆ£xâƒ—âˆ£vâƒ—â‹…yâƒ—=cosâ¡(Ï†)âˆ£vâƒ—âˆ£âˆ£yâƒ—âˆ£\begin{alignat*}{3} \vec{v} \cdot \vec{x} &= \cos(\Theta) |\vec{v}| |\vec{x}| \\ \vec{v} \cdot \vec{y} &= \cos(\varphi) |\vec{v}| |\vec{y}| \end{alignat*}vâ‹…xvâ‹…yâ€‹â€‹=cos(Î˜)âˆ£vâˆ£âˆ£xâˆ£=cos(Ï†)âˆ£vâˆ£âˆ£yâ€‹âˆ£â€‹

Since âˆ£xâƒ—âˆ£=âˆ£yâƒ—âˆ£=1|\vec{x}| = |\vec{y}| = 1âˆ£xâˆ£=âˆ£yâ€‹âˆ£=1, we find

vâƒ—â‹…xâƒ—=cosâ¡(Î˜)âˆ£vâƒ—âˆ£vâƒ—â‹…yâƒ—=cosâ¡(Ï†)âˆ£vâƒ—âˆ£\begin{alignat*}{3} \vec{v} \cdot \vec{x} &= \cos(\Theta) |\vec{v}|\\ \vec{v} \cdot \vec{y} &= \cos(\varphi) |\vec{v}| \end{alignat*}vâ‹…xvâ‹…yâ€‹â€‹=cos(Î˜)âˆ£vâˆ£=cos(Ï†)âˆ£vâˆ£â€‹

We now solve for aaa and bbb. Since vâƒ—=axâƒ—+byâƒ—\vec{v} = a\vec{x} + b \vec{y}v=ax+byâ€‹, we have

vâƒ—â‹…xâƒ—=(axâƒ—+byâƒ—)â‹…xâƒ—=a(âˆ£xâƒ—âˆ£2)+b(xâƒ—â‹…yâƒ—)\begin{split} \vec{v} \cdot \vec{x} &= (a\vec{x} + b \vec{y}) \cdot \vec{x} \\ &= a(|\vec{x}|^2) + b( \vec{x} \cdot \vec{y}) \\ \end{split}vâ‹…xâ€‹=(ax+byâ€‹)â‹…x=a(âˆ£xâˆ£2)+b(xâ‹…yâ€‹)â€‹

Since xâƒ—â‹…yâƒ—=0\vec{x} \cdot \vec{y} = 0xâ‹…yâ€‹=0 and âˆ£xâƒ—âˆ£=1|\vec{x}| = 1âˆ£xâˆ£=1, we have

vâƒ—â‹…xâƒ—=a\begin{split} \vec{v} \cdot \vec{x} = a \\ \end{split}vâ‹…x=aâ€‹

Solving analogously for bbb, we obtain

vâƒ—â‹…yâƒ—=b\begin{split} \vec{v} \cdot \vec{y} = b \\ \end{split}vâ‹…yâ€‹=bâ€‹

We have shown that

vâƒ—â‹…xâƒ—=cosâ¡(Î˜)âˆ£vâƒ—âˆ£=avâƒ—â‹…yâƒ—=cosâ¡(Ï†)âˆ£vâƒ—âˆ£=b\begin{alignat*}{3} \vec{v} \cdot \vec{x} &= \cos(\Theta) |\vec{v}| &&= a\\ \vec{v} \cdot \vec{y} &= \cos(\varphi) |\vec{v}| && = b \end{alignat*}vâ‹…xvâ‹…yâ€‹â€‹=cos(Î˜)âˆ£vâˆ£=cos(Ï†)âˆ£vâˆ£â€‹â€‹=a=bâ€‹

and substitute into the linear combination:

vâƒ—=axâƒ—+byâƒ—=cosâ¡(Î˜)âˆ£vâƒ—âˆ£xâƒ—+cosâ¡(Ï†)âˆ£vâƒ—âˆ£yâƒ—\begin{alignat*}{3} \vec{v} &= a \vec{x} + b \vec{y} \\ &= \cos(\Theta) |\vec{v}| \vec{x} + \cos(\varphi) |\vec{v}| \vec{y} \end{alignat*}vâ€‹=ax+byâ€‹=cos(Î˜)âˆ£vâˆ£x+cos(Ï†)âˆ£vâˆ£yâ€‹â€‹

From âˆ (xâƒ—,yâƒ—)=Ï€2\angle(\vec{x}, \vec{y}) = \frac{\pi}{2}âˆ (x,yâ€‹)=2Ï€â€‹ we can derive

cosâ¡(Ï†)=cosâ¡(Ï€2␀âˆ’Î˜)=cosâ¡(Ï€2)cosâ¡(Î˜)+sinâ¡(Ï€2)sinâ¡(Î˜)=sinâ¡(Î˜)\begin{equation}\notag \begin{split} \cos(\varphi) &= \cos(\frac{\pi}{2} - \Theta) \\ &= \cos(\frac{\pi}{2})\cos(\Theta) + \sin(\frac{\pi}{2})\sin(\Theta)\\ &= \sin(\Theta) \end{split} \end{equation}cos(Ï†)â€‹=cos(2Ï€â€‹âˆ’Î˜)=cos(2Ï€â€‹)cos(Î˜)+sin(2Ï€â€‹)sin(Î˜)=sin(Î˜)â€‹â€‹

and finally rewrite the linear combination as

vâƒ—=cosâ¡(Î˜)âˆ£vâƒ—âˆ£xâƒ—+sinâ¡(Î˜)âˆ£vâƒ—âˆ£yâƒ—\vec{v} = \cos(\Theta) |\vec{v}| \vec{x} + \sin(\Theta) |\vec{v}| \vec{y}v=cos(Î˜)âˆ£vâˆ£x+sin(Î˜)âˆ£vâˆ£yâ€‹

Dividing by âˆ£vâƒ—âˆ£|\vec{v}|âˆ£vâˆ£ yields the normalized vector v^\hat{v}v^. We therefore receive

vâƒ—âˆ£vâƒ—âˆ£=v^=cosâ¡(Î˜)xâƒ—+sinâ¡(Î˜)yâƒ—\frac{\vec{v}}{|\vec{v}|} = \hat{v} = \cos(\Theta) \vec{x} + \sin(\Theta) \vec{y}âˆ£vâˆ£vâ€‹=v^=cos(Î˜)x+sin(Î˜)yâ€‹

â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Verifying the normalizationâ€‹

Under the given assumptions, we verify that âˆ£v^âˆ£=1|\hat{v}| = 1âˆ£v^âˆ£=1, confirming that v^\hat{v}v^ is normalized:

âˆ£v^âˆ£=âˆ£axâƒ—+byâƒ—âˆ£=âˆ£a(x1,x2)T+b(y1,y2)Tâˆ£=(ax1+by1)2+(ax2+by2)2=a2x12+a2x22+b2y12+b2y22+2abx1y1+2abx2y2=a2(x12+x22)+b2(y12+y22)+2ab(x1y1+x2y2)=a2(xâƒ—â‹…xâƒ—)+b2(yâƒ—â‹…yâƒ—)+2ab(xâƒ—â‹…yâƒ—)=a2+b2+2ab0=a2+b2\begin{equation}\notag \begin{split} |\hat{v}| &= |a \vec{x} + b \vec{y}| \\ &= |a (x_1, x_2)^T + b (y_1, y_2)^T| \\ &= \sqrt{(ax_1 + by_1)^2 + (ax_2 + by_2)^2} \\ &= \sqrt{a^2x_1^2 + a^2x_2^2 + b^2y_1^2 + b^2y_2^2 + 2abx_1y_1 + 2abx_2y_2 } \\ &= \sqrt{a^2(x_1^2 + x_2^2) + b^2(y_1^2 + y_2^2) + 2ab(x_1y_1 + x_2y_2)} \\ &= \sqrt{a^2(\vec{x} \cdot \vec{x} ) + b^2(\vec{y} \cdot \vec{y}) + 2ab(\vec{x} \cdot \vec{y})} \\ &= \sqrt{a^2 + b^2 + 2ab0} \\ &= \sqrt{a^2 + b^2} \end{split} \end{equation}âˆ£v^âˆ£â€‹=âˆ£ax+byâ€‹âˆ£=âˆ£a(x1â€‹,x2â€‹)T+b(y1â€‹,y2â€‹)Tâˆ£=(ax1â€‹+by1â€‹)2+(ax2â€‹+by2â€‹)2â€‹=a2x12â€‹+a2x22â€‹+b2y12â€‹+b2y22â€‹+2abx1â€‹y1â€‹+2abx2â€‹y2â€‹â€‹=a2(x12â€‹+x22â€‹)+b2(y12â€‹+y22â€‹)+2ab(x1â€‹y1â€‹+x2â€‹y2â€‹)â€‹=a2(xâ‹…x)+b2(yâ€‹â‹…yâ€‹)+2ab(xâ‹…yâ€‹)â€‹=a2+b2+2ab0â€‹=a2+b2â€‹â€‹â€‹

In order for âˆ£v^âˆ£=1|\hat{v}| = 1âˆ£v^âˆ£=1 to hold, it is required that a2+b2=1a^2 + b^2 = 1a2+b2=1, as given by the assumption.

Substituting aaa and bbb by cosâ¡(Î˜)\cos(\Theta)cos(Î˜) and sinâ¡(Î˜)\sin(\Theta)sin(Î˜), respectively, we confirm that

cosâ¡2(Î˜)+sinâ¡2(Î˜)=1\cos^2(\Theta) + \sin^2(\Theta) = 1cos2(Î˜)+sin2(Î˜)=1

â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Determining the angle Î¸ between the vectorsâ€‹

Claim: Î˜\ThetaÎ˜ is the angle between v^,xâƒ—\hat{v}, \vec{x}v^,x.

This follows trivially since we have already shown that both v^\hat{v}v^ and xâƒ—\vec{x}x are unit vectors. By definition of the dot product, we have:

v^â‹…xâƒ—=cosâ¡(Î˜)âˆ£v^âˆ£âˆ£xâƒ—âˆ£=cosâ¡(Î˜)\begin{alignat*}{3} \hat{v} \cdot \vec{x} &= \cos(\Theta) |\hat{v}| |\vec{x}| \\ &= \cos(\Theta) \end{alignat*}v^â‹…xâ€‹=cos(Î˜)âˆ£v^âˆ£âˆ£xâˆ£=cos(Î˜)â€‹

which is illustrated in Figure 1.

â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Generalization to arbitrary lengthsâ€‹

One particular result we get from this - and which will be useful when applying rotations in R3\mathbb{R}^3R3 around arbitrary axes - is the fact that, for any perpendicular vectors xâƒ—,yâƒ—âˆˆR2\vec{x}, \vec{y} \in \mathbb{R}^2x,yâ€‹âˆˆR2, where âˆ£xâƒ—âˆ£=âˆ£yâƒ—âˆ£|\vec{x}| = |\vec{y}|âˆ£xâˆ£=âˆ£yâ€‹âˆ£, the linear combination

vâƒ—=cosâ¡(Î˜)xâƒ—+sinâ¡(Î˜)yâƒ—\vec{v} = \cos(\Theta) \vec{x} + \sin(\Theta) \vec{y}v=cos(Î˜)x+sin(Î˜)yâ€‹

yields a vector vâƒ—\vec{v}v satisfying

âˆ£vâƒ—âˆ£=âˆ£xâƒ—âˆ£=âˆ£yâƒ—âˆ£|\vec{v}| = |\vec{x}| = |\vec{y}|âˆ£vâˆ£=âˆ£xâˆ£=âˆ£yâ€‹âˆ£

Following the previous proof, we now treat xâƒ—,yâƒ—\vec{x}, \vec{y}x,yâ€‹ as vectors with arbitrary, but equal length, resulting in the (normalized) linear combination

v^=cosâ¡(Î˜)xâƒ—âˆ£xâƒ—âˆ£+sinâ¡(Î˜)yâƒ—âˆ£yâƒ—âˆ£\hat{v} = \cos(\Theta) \frac{\vec{x}}{|\vec{x}|} + \sin(\Theta)\frac{\vec{y}}{|\vec{y}|}v^=cos(Î˜)âˆ£xâˆ£xâ€‹+sin(Î˜)âˆ£yâ€‹âˆ£yâ€‹â€‹

To cancel out the denominators on the right-hand side, we multiply the equation by âˆ£xâƒ—âˆ£|\vec{x}|âˆ£xâˆ£3, yielding

v^âˆ£xâƒ—âˆ£=cosâ¡(Î˜)xâƒ—+sinâ¡(Î˜)yâƒ—\hat{v}|\vec{x}| = \cos(\Theta) \vec{x} + \sin(\Theta) \vec{y}v^âˆ£xâˆ£=cos(Î˜)x+sin(Î˜)yâ€‹

Thus, we obtain a vector with the same magnitude as xâƒ—\vec{x}x and yâƒ—\vec{y}yâ€‹. â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Rotation around arbitrary pointsâ€‹

When rotating a point by a given angle, the transformation depends on the chosen center of rotation.

Figure 2 illustrates the point p=(6,4)p = (6, 4)p=(6,4) rotated by Î˜=20Â°\Theta = 20 \degreeÎ˜=20Â°. Here, ppp is rotated around the origin (0,0)(0, 0)(0,0) of the coordinate plane, resulting in pâ€²p'pâ€², which can be obtained via the matrix-vector product

R(Î˜)â‹…pâƒ—=pâ€²âƒ—\boldsymbol{R}(\Theta) \cdot \vec{p} = \vec{p'}R(Î˜)â‹…pâ€‹=pâ€²â€‹

where4

R(Î˜)=(cosâ¡Î˜âˆ’sinâ¡Î˜sinâ¡Î˜cosâ¡Î˜)\boldsymbol{R}(\Theta) = \begin{pmatrix} \cos \Theta & -\sin \Theta \\ \sin \Theta & \cos \Theta \end{pmatrix}R(Î˜)=(cosÎ˜sinÎ˜â€‹âˆ’sinÎ˜cosÎ˜â€‹)
Figure 2 The point p is rotated around the origin by Î¸ degree, yielding p'.
Plot-Code (Python)
import numpy as np
import math
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from matplotlib.patches import Arc
from matplotlib.ticker import MultipleLocator
from matplotlib.patches import Wedge

# plot layout
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(6, 6))
ax.set_xlim(-1, 8)
ax.set_ylim(-1, 8)
ax.set_aspect('equal')
ax.set_xlabel("x")
ax.set_ylabel("y")

ax.axvline(0, color='black', linewidth=1.5)
ax.xaxis.set_major_locator(MultipleLocator(1))
ax.yaxis.set_major_locator(MultipleLocator(1))

theta = math.radians(20)

p_x = 6
p_y = 4
pc = 'blue'

r_x = 2
r_y = 3
rc = 'red'

# point

ax.quiver(0, 0, p_x, p_y, angles='xy', scale_units='xy', scale=1, color=pc, width=0.005, linestyle='--',alpha=0.2)

# center of rotation
r = np.array([r_x, r_y])
#ax.quiver(0, 0, r_x, r_y, angles='xy', scale_units='xy', scale=1, color=rc, width=0.005, linestyle='--',alpha=0.2)

# rotated p

    p_x * np.cos(theta) - p_y * np.sin(theta),
    p_x * np.sin(theta) + p_y * np.cos(theta)
])
ax.quiver(0, 0, pr[0], pr[1], angles='xy', scale_units='xy', scale=1, color=pc, width=0.005, linestyle='--',alpha=0.2)

# p, p'

          arc_radius,
          arc_radius,
          angle=0,

          theta2=20 + np.degrees(np.arctan2(p_y, p_x)),
          edgecolor=pc)

plt.show()

Choosing a different center of rotationâ€‹

Figure 3 illustrates the rotation around rrr. pâ€²âƒ—\vec{p'}pâ€²â€‹ is computed such that

  • the rotation center rrr becomes the origin of all points in the coordinate plane
  • rotation is applied
  • the rotated point is translated back.

Using râƒ—=rT\vec{r} = r^Tr=rT, we get the expression:

R(Î˜)(pâƒ—âˆ’râƒ—)+râƒ—\boldsymbol{R}(\Theta) (\vec{p} - \vec{r}) + \vec{r}R(Î˜)(pâ€‹âˆ’r)+r
Figure 1 The point p gets translated, then rotated around the origin, then translated back to p'.

Constructing an orthogonal basis for linear combinationâ€‹

As an alternative to explicitly translating a point to the origin, applying rotation and translating it back, we can directly construct an orthogonal basis around rpâƒ—\vec{rp}rpâ€‹ and express the rotated point as a linear combination, as shown in the previous section:

pâ€²âƒ—=cosâ¡(Î˜)rpâƒ—+sinâ¡(Î˜)rpâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{p'} = \cos(\Theta) \vec{rp} + \sin(\Theta) \vec{rp}_{\perp}pâ€²â€‹=cos(Î˜)rpâ€‹+sin(Î˜)rpâ€‹âŠ¥â€‹

Here, rpâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{rp}_{\perp}rpâ€‹âŠ¥â€‹ is the vector perpendicular to rpâƒ—\vec{rp}rpâ€‹ with the same magnitude, i.e. âˆ£rpâƒ—âŠ¥âˆ£=âˆ£rpâƒ—âˆ£|\vec{rp}_{\perp}| = |\vec{rp}|âˆ£rpâ€‹âŠ¥â€‹âˆ£=âˆ£rpâ€‹âˆ£.

To obtain rpâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{rp}_{\perp}rpâ€‹âŠ¥â€‹, we present two practical methods:

  1. Using the vector cross product:
    The vector cross product wâƒ—Ã—rpâƒ—\vec{w} \times \vec{rp}wÃ—rpâ€‹ yields a vector rpâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{rp}_{\perp}rpâ€‹âŠ¥â€‹ orthogonal to both rpâƒ—\vec{rp}rpâ€‹ and wâƒ—\vec{w}w.

    wâƒ—\vec{w}w is unknown and therefor has to be computed.

    Since the vector cross product is an operation inherently defined in R3\mathbb{R}^3R3, we need to temporarily extend our vector by a third component: For rpâƒ—\vec{rp}rpâ€‹, we write (rpâƒ—x,rpâƒ—y,0)(\vec{rp}_x, \vec{rp}_y, 0)(rpâ€‹xâ€‹,rpâ€‹yâ€‹,0).

    For wâƒ—\vec{w}w, we choose a unit vector along the zzz-axis, (0,0,1)T(0, 0 , 1)^T(0,0,1)T, which is perpendicular to our 2-dimensional plane. We then calculate

    rpâƒ—âŠ¥=(001)Ã—(rpâƒ—xrpâƒ—y0)=(âˆ’rpâƒ—yrpâƒ—x0)\vec{rp}_{\perp} = \begin{pmatrix}0 \\ 0 \\ 1\end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix}\vec{rp}_x \\ \vec{rp}_y \\ 0\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} - \vec{rp}_y \\ \vec{rp}_x \\ 0\end{pmatrix}rpâ€‹âŠ¥â€‹=â€‹001â€‹â€‹Ã—â€‹rpâ€‹xâ€‹rpâ€‹yâ€‹0â€‹â€‹=â€‹âˆ’rpâ€‹yâ€‹rpâ€‹xâ€‹0â€‹â€‹

    Dropping the third component in the resulting vector, we end up with rpâƒ—âŠ¥=(âˆ’rpâƒ—y,rpâƒ—x)T\vec{rp}_{\perp} = (- \vec{rp}_y, \vec{rp}_x)^Trpâ€‹âŠ¥â€‹=(âˆ’rpâ€‹yâ€‹,rpâ€‹xâ€‹)T, which is perpendicular to rpâƒ—\vec{rp}rpâ€‹, as verified by their dot product:

    (âˆ’rpâƒ—y,rpâƒ—x)Tâ‹…(rpâƒ—x,rpâƒ—y)T=âˆ’rpâƒ—yrpâƒ—x+rpâƒ—xrpâƒ—y=0(- \vec{rp}_y, \vec{rp}_x)^T \cdot (\vec{rp}_x, \vec{rp}_y)^T = -\vec{rp}_y \vec{rp}_x + \vec{rp}_x \vec{rp}_y = 0(âˆ’rpâ€‹yâ€‹,rpâ€‹xâ€‹)Tâ‹…(rpâ€‹xâ€‹,rpâ€‹yâ€‹)T=âˆ’rpâ€‹yâ€‹rpâ€‹xâ€‹+rpâ€‹xâ€‹rpâ€‹yâ€‹=0

    In fact, the resulting vector rpâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{rp}_{\perp}rpâ€‹âŠ¥â€‹ is simply rpâƒ—\vec{rp}rpâ€‹ rotated by 90Â°90\degree90Â° counterclockwise, which will be formally verified with the next method.

  2. Using the rotation matrix:
    By substituting Î˜=Ï€2\Theta = \frac{\pi}{2}Î˜=2Ï€â€‹ (90Â°90\degree90Â°) into the rotation matrix R(Î˜)\boldsymbol{R}(\Theta)R(Î˜), we get:

    R(Ï€2)=(cosâ¡Ï€2âˆ’sinÏ€2sinâ¡Ï€2cosâ¡Ï€2)=(0âˆ’110) \boldsymbol{R}(\frac{\pi}{2}) = \begin{pmatrix}\cos \frac{\pi}{2} & -sin \frac{\pi}{2} \\ \sin \frac{\pi}{2} & \cos \frac{\pi}{2} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}0 & -1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}R(2Ï€â€‹)=(cos2Ï€â€‹sin2Ï€â€‹â€‹âˆ’sin2Ï€â€‹cos2Ï€â€‹â€‹)=(01â€‹âˆ’10â€‹)

    Multiplying R(Ï€2)\boldsymbol{R}(\frac{\pi}{2})R(2Ï€â€‹) with rpâƒ—\vec{rp}rpâ€‹, we obtain the perpendicular vector:

    R(Ï€2)rpâƒ—=(0âˆ’110)(rpâƒ—xrpâƒ—y)=(âˆ’rpâƒ—yrpâƒ—x)=rpâƒ—âŠ¥\boldsymbol{R}(\frac{\pi}{2}) \vec{rp} = \begin{pmatrix}0 & -1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \vec{rp}_x \\ \vec{rp}_y \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -\vec{rp}_y \\ \vec{rp}_x \end{pmatrix} = \vec{rp}_{\perp}R(2Ï€â€‹)rpâ€‹=(01â€‹âˆ’10â€‹)(rpâ€‹xâ€‹rpâ€‹yâ€‹â€‹)=(âˆ’rpâ€‹yâ€‹rpâ€‹xâ€‹â€‹)=rpâ€‹âŠ¥â€‹

    which also confirms the claim above: rpâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{rp}_{\perp}rpâ€‹âŠ¥â€‹ represents rpâƒ—\vec{rp}rpâ€‹ rotated by 90Â°90\degree90Â° ccw.

In both cases, rpâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{rp}_\perprpâ€‹âŠ¥â€‹ can be used for finalizing the linear combination as

pâ€²âƒ—=cosâ¡(Î˜)rpâƒ—+sinâ¡(Î˜)rpâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{p'} = \cos(\Theta) \vec{rp} + \sin(\Theta) \vec{rp}_{\perp}pâ€²â€‹=cos(Î˜)rpâ€‹+sin(Î˜)rpâ€‹âŠ¥â€‹

â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Without delving into the complexity of the involved operations, it should be evident that translating, rotating by R(Î˜)\boldsymbol{R}(\Theta)R(Î˜), then translating back is more efficient when operating on a large number of vectors, as it avoids computing an orthogonal basis for each case. However, constructing such a basis becomes necessary when rotations around arbitrary axes must be performed, a topic we will address in the next section.

3D Rotation about an Arbitrary Axisâ€‹

Rodrigues' Rotation Formulaâ€‹

Rotation of vectors about an arbitrary vector nâƒ—âˆˆR3\vec{n} \in \mathbb{R}^3nâˆˆR3 in three dimensions involves a combination of vector projection and the use of a locally defined two-dimensional orthogonal basis. The general method for computing such rotations is also known as the Rodrigues formula5:

vâ€²âƒ—=vâƒ—âˆ¥+cosâ¡(Î˜)vâƒ—âŠ¥+sinâ¡(Î˜)wâƒ—\vec{v'} = \vec{v}_{\parallel} + \cos(\Theta) \vec{v}_{\perp} + \sin(\Theta) \vec{w}vâ€²=vâˆ¥â€‹+cos(Î˜)vâŠ¥â€‹+sin(Î˜)w

or, in its commonly used compact form

vâƒ—â€²=vâƒ—cosâ¡(Î˜)+((vâƒ—â‹…n^)â‹…n^)(1âˆ’cosâ¡(Î˜))+(n^Ã—vâƒ—)sinâ¡(Î˜)\vec{v}' = \vec{v} \cos(\Theta) + ((\vec{v} \cdot \hat{n}) \cdot \hat{n})(1 - \cos(\Theta)) + (\hat{n} \times \vec{v})\sin(\Theta)vâ€²=vcos(Î˜)+((vâ‹…n^)â‹…n^)(1âˆ’cos(Î˜))+(n^Ã—v)sin(Î˜)

We will now proceed to derive the formula, with a special focus on obtaining wâƒ—\vec{w}w which represents a coordinate axis in a locally defined orthogonal basis with equal-length axes.

In Figure 4, the vector vâƒ—\vec{v}v is rotated about the axis nâƒ—\vec{n}n. Since we do not care about the magnitude of nâƒ—\vec{n}n, but rather its direction, we normalize the vector and obtain n^\hat{n}n^, which will be the center of rotation for vâƒ—\vec{v}v in the following derivation.

Figure 4 Visualization of Rodrigues' rotation formula applied to vector v, rotated 45Â° around the axis n. Also shown is the decomposition into the parallel and orthogonal components. A second rotation by 90Â° demonstrates that the parallel component remains unchanged, while only the perpendicular part (the rejection) undergoes rotation in the locally defined two-dimensional plane.
Plot-Code (Python)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import math

def arc(ax, center, v1, v2, theta_start, theta_end, r=1.0, steps=100, **kwargs):
    thetas = np.linspace(theta_start, theta_end, steps)
    arc_points = np.array([
        center + r * (np.cos(t) * v1 + np.sin(t) * v2) for t in thetas
    ])

    if kwargs.get('arrow', True):
        theta = thetas[-1]
        tangent = np.cos(theta)*v2 - np.sin(theta)*v1
        tangent = tangent / np.linalg.norm(tangent)

        arrow_end = arc_points[-1]
        arrow_start = arrow_end - 0.01 * tangent
        ax.quiver(*arrow_start, *tangent, length=0.01,
                  arrow_length_ratio=20, linewidth=1, color=kwargs.get('color', 'black'))

    ax.plot(arc_points[:, 0], arc_points[:, 1], arc_points[:, 2], **kwargs)

def rodrigues(theta, v, n):
    vn = v / np.linalg.norm(v)
    nn = n / np.linalg.norm(n)
    vpar = np.dot(nn, v) * nn
    vperp = v - vpar

    return vpar + (np.cos(theta) * (vperp)) + (np.sin(theta) * np.cross(nn, v))

####################
## CANVAS
####################
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10, 10))
ax = fig.add_subplot(projection='3d')

ax.set_xlim([0, 6])
ax.set_ylim([0, 6])
ax.set_zlim([0, 6])

ax.set_xlabel('x')
ax.set_ylabel('y')
ax.set_zlabel('z')

ax.quiver(0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0, color='grey', length=6, arrow_length_ratio=0.04)
ax.quiver(0, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, color='grey', length=6, arrow_length_ratio=0.04)
ax.quiver(0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, color='grey', length=6, arrow_length_ratio=0.04)

ax.view_init(elev=10, azim=-45)


####################
## Parameters
####################
origin = np.array([0, 1, 2])


v = np.array([0, 4, 3])
n = np.array([0, 6, 0])

nn = n / np.linalg.norm(n)

#v
ax.quiver(*origin, *v, color='black',  arrow_length_ratio=0.05)
ax.text(*(v + [0, -2.0, -1.2] + origin), r'$\vec{v}$', color='black', fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')

# v parallel
vpar =  np.dot(v, nn) * nn
ax.quiver(*(origin + nn), *(vpar - nn), color='green', linewidth=1, alpha=0.7,  arrow_length_ratio=0.1)
ax.text(*(vpar + [0, -1.2, 0.2] + origin), r'$\vec{v}_{\parallel}$', color='green', fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')

#v rotated - demo
vdemo = rodrigues(math.pi / 2, v, n)
ax.quiver(*origin, *vdemo, color='black', linewidth=1, alpha=0.7,  arrow_length_ratio=0.05)
ax.text(*(vdemo + [0, -2.4, -0] + origin), r'$\vec{v}_{90^\circ}$', color='black', fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')

#v rotated
vrot = rodrigues(math.pi / 4, v, n)
ax.quiver(*origin, *vrot, color='black', linewidth=1, alpha=0.7,  arrow_length_ratio=0.05)
ax.text(*(vrot + [0, -1.4, -0.2] + origin), r"$\vec{v}'$", color='black', fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')

# v perp
vperp = v - vpar
ax.quiver(*(vpar + origin), *vperp, color='blue', linewidth=1, alpha=0.7,  arrow_length_ratio=0.15)
ax.text(*(vpar +[-0.4, 0, 1.2]  + origin), r'$\vec{v}_{\perp}$', color='blue', fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')

#w
w = np.cross(nn, v)
ax.quiver(*(vpar + origin), *w, color='red', linewidth=1, alpha=0.7,  arrow_length_ratio=0.1)
ax.text(*(vpar +[2, 0, 0.08] + origin), r'$\vec{w}$', color='red', fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')


# v perp 45 degrees
vperp45 = np.cos(math.pi/4) * vperp + np.sin(math.pi/4) * w
ax.quiver(*(vpar + origin), *vperp45, color='blue', linewidth=0.5, alpha=0.7,  arrow_length_ratio=0.15)
ax.text(*(vpar + vperp45 + [0, -0.6, -0.8] + origin), r"$\vec{v}'_{\perp}$", color='blue', fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')


#n unit n
ax.quiver(*(origin + vpar), *(n - vpar), color='green', linewidth=1,  arrow_length_ratio=0.15)
ax.text(*(origin + vpar + [0, 0.8, 0.15]), r"$\vec{n}$", color='green', fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')

ax.quiver(*origin, *nn, color='green', linewidth=1,  arrow_length_ratio=0.3)
ax.text(*(origin + nn + [0, -0.6, -0.4]), r"$\hat{n}$", color='green', fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')


arc(ax, center=origin + vpar, v1=vperp, v2=w,
            theta_start=0, theta_end=np.pi/4, r=1,
            color='purple', alpha=0.5, linewidth=1, linestyle='dashed')
ax.text(*(vrot + [0, -1.1, 1.2] + origin), r'$45^\circ$', color='purple', fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')


plt.subplots_adjust(left=0, right=1, top=1, bottom=0)
plt.show()

Clearly, rotating one vector about another vector in 3D must preserve at least one component of the vector that never changes, specifically the one aligned with the axis of rotation. To illustrate this, consider the special case of rotation about one of the standard basis vectors in R3\mathbb{R}^3R3:

xâƒ—=(100),yâƒ—=(010),zâƒ—=(001)\vec{x} = \begin{pmatrix}1 \\ 0 \\ 0\end{pmatrix}, \vec{y} = \begin{pmatrix}0 \\ 1 \\ 0\end{pmatrix}, \vec{z} = \begin{pmatrix}0 \\ 0 \\ 1\end{pmatrix}x=â€‹100â€‹â€‹,yâ€‹=â€‹010â€‹â€‹,z=â€‹001â€‹â€‹

For example, rotation of a point (x,y)(x, y)(x,y) in the Euclidean plane corresponds to rotating the point (x,y,s)(x, y, s)(x,y,s) in three-dimensional space about the zzz-axis: Here, the zzz-component sss always stays unchanged, e.g.

Rz(Î˜)(xys)=(xâ€²yâ€²s)\boldsymbol{R}_z(\Theta) \begin{pmatrix}x\\ y\\ s\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}x'\\ y'\\ s\end{pmatrix}Rzâ€‹(Î˜)â€‹xysâ€‹â€‹=â€‹xâ€²yâ€²sâ€‹â€‹

Analogous reasoning applies to rotation about the xxx-axis and yyy-axis, where the respective components remain constant.

Applying the rules of vector projection in an orthonormal basis - or an orthogonal basis with equal axis lengths, as we will see shortly - helps us isolate the component of a vector that remains unchanged under rotation. Illustrated in Figure 5 is the orthogonal projection of a vector aâƒ—\vec{a}a onto another vector bâƒ—\vec{b}b, which yields the component of aâƒ—\vec{a}a parallel to bâƒ—\vec{b}b.

aâƒ—âˆ¥=aâƒ—â‹…bâƒ—âˆ£bâƒ—âˆ£2â‹…bâƒ—\vec{a}_{\parallel} = \frac{\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b}}{|\vec{b}|^2} \cdot \vec{b}aâˆ¥â€‹=âˆ£bâˆ£2aâ‹…bâ€‹â‹…b
Figure 5 Orthogonal projection of a vector a onto a vector b. The projection of a onto b represents the parallel component of vector a into the direction of vector b, the rejection of a from b the component perpendicular to b.
Plot-Code (Python)
import numpy as np
import math
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from matplotlib.patches import Arc
from matplotlib.ticker import MultipleLocator

# plot layout
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(6, 6))
ax.set_xlim(0, 6)
ax.set_ylim(-1, 4)
ax.set_aspect('equal')
ax.set_xlabel("x")
ax.set_ylabel("y")
ax.grid(False)
ax.axhline(0, color='black', linewidth=1.0)
ax.axvline(0, color='black', linewidth=1.0)
ax.xaxis.set_major_locator(MultipleLocator(1))
ax.yaxis.set_major_locator(MultipleLocator(1))

origin = np.array([0, 0])
a = np.array([4, 3])
b = np.array([5, 0])

bn = b / np.linalg.norm(b)

apar = np.dot(a, bn) * bn
aperp = a - apar

ax.quiver(*origin, *a, angles='xy', scale_units='xy', scale=1, color='red')
ax.quiver(*origin, *b, angles='xy', scale_units='xy', scale=1, color='blue')

ax.quiver(*origin, *apar, angles='xy', scale_units='xy', scale=1, color='red')
ax.quiver(*(origin + apar), *aperp, angles='xy', scale_units='xy', width=0.005, scale=1, color='red')
ax.quiver(*origin, *bn, angles='xy', scale_units='xy', scale=1, color='blue')

ax.text(*(apar + aperp - [-0.2, 1.5]), r'$\vec{a}_{\perp} = \vec{a} - \vec{a}_{\parallel}$', color='red', fontsize=12)
ax.text(*(a - [2.5, 1.5]), r'$\vec{a}$', color='red', fontsize=12)
ax.text(*(bn - [0.5, 0.5]), r'$\hat{b}$', color='blue', fontsize=12)
ax.text(*(apar - apar/2 - [0.5 , 0.5]), r'$\hat{a}_{\parallel} = \frac{\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b}}{|\vec{b}|^2}\cdot\vec{b}$', color='red', fontsize=12)
ax.text(*(b - [0.5, 0.5]), r'$\vec{b}$', color='blue', fontsize=12)

plt.show()

Here, aâƒ—âˆ¥\vec{a}_{\parallel}aâˆ¥â€‹ represents the xxx-component of vector aâƒ—\vec{a}a in the direction of bâƒ—\vec{b}b, while the orthogonal (or "sifted out") yyy-component is given by aâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{a}_{\perp}aâŠ¥â€‹:

aâƒ—âŠ¥=aâƒ—âˆ’aâƒ—âˆ¥\vec{a}_{\perp} = \vec{a} - \vec{a}_{\parallel}aâŠ¥â€‹=aâˆ’aâˆ¥â€‹
note

It might at first seem confusing that both the parallel and the perpendicular component change under rotation in two dimensions, whereas we previously stated that the projection parallel to the rotation axis remains constant. This raises the question: Where is the rotation axis located in the Euclidean space? Obviously, there is none, as Foley et al. point out6.

This apparent discrepancy resolves once we explicitly construct the rotation axis outside the plane, effectively embedding the plane into a higher dimensional-space.

As demonstrated above, a 2D rotation can be represented in 3D by considering vectors lying in an xyxyxy-plane, perpendicular to the zzz-axis (see Figure 6).

Figure 6 Vector a lies in the xy-plane and is rotated around the z-axis. Any projection of a onto the z-axis must be zero since a is perpendicular to z.
Plot-Code (Python)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import math


#################
# Canvas
#################
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10, 10))
ax = fig.add_subplot(projection='3d')

ax.set_xlim([-12, 12])
ax.set_ylim([-12, 12])
ax.set_zlim([-12, 12])

ax.set_xticks(np.arange(-12, 13, 2))
ax.set_yticks(np.arange(-12, 13, 2))
ax.set_zticks(np.arange(-12, 13, 2))

ax.set_xlabel('x')
ax.set_ylabel('y')
ax.set_zlabel('z')

origin = np.array([0, 0, 0])

ax.quiver(*origin, 1, 0, 0, color='red', length=12, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)
ax.quiver(*origin, -1, 0, 0, color='red', length=12, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)
ax.quiver(*origin, 0, 1, 0, color='green', length=12, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)
ax.quiver(*origin, 0, -1, 0, color='green', length=12, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)
ax.quiver(*origin, 0, 0, 1, color='blue', length=12, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)
ax.quiver(*origin, 0, 0, -1, color='blue', length=12, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)

# data
x = np.linspace(-12, 12, 2)
y = np.linspace(-12, 12, 2)
x, y = np.meshgrid(x, y)
z = np.zeros_like(x)
ax.plot_surface(x, y, z, color='lightblue', alpha=0.4)

a = np.array([12, -8, 0])
b = np.array([0, -8, 0])

bn = b / np.linalg.norm(b)

apar = np.dot(a, bn) * bn
aperp = a - apar

ax.quiver(*origin, *a, color='black', length=1, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)
ax.quiver(*origin, *b, color='black', length=1, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)
ax.quiver(*apar, *(aperp), color='black', length=1, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)

ax.text(*origin + [0, -4, 1], r'$\vec{a}_{\parallel}$', color='black', fontsize=12)
ax.text(*origin + [14, 0, 0.5], r'$\vec{a}$', color='black', fontsize=12)
ax.text(*origin + [14, 0, 3.5], r'$\vec{a}_{\perp}$', color='black', fontsize=12)

ax.view_init(elev=10, azim=45)
plt.subplots_adjust(left=0, right=1, top=1, bottom=0)

plt.show()

Here, the orthogonal projection - the parallel component - of any rotated vector onto the rotation axis is always 0âƒ—\vec{0}0 - which corresponds exactly to the situation in two-dimensional rotation. This follows directly from the dot product.

However, once we tilt the plane slightly, such that vectors take the form (x,y,s)T(x, y, s)^T(x,y,s)T with (x,y,s)Tâ‹…(0,0,1)Tâ‰ 0(x, y, s)^T \cdot (0, 0 , 1)^T \neq 0(x,y,s)Tâ‹…(0,0,1)Tî€ =0, the parallel components of these vectors become nonzero and remain fixed under rotation (see Figure 7).

Figure 7 The xy-plane is now tilted. Vector a rotates around the z-axis. Unlike before, its projection onto the z-axis is non-zero, yet it remains fixed under rotation.
Plot-Code (Python)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import math


#################
# Canvas
#################
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10, 10))
ax = fig.add_subplot(projection='3d')

ax.set_xlim([-12, 12])
ax.set_ylim([-12, 12])
ax.set_zlim([-12, 12])

ax.set_xticks(np.arange(-12, 13, 2))
ax.set_yticks(np.arange(-12, 13, 2))
ax.set_zticks(np.arange(-12, 13, 2))

ax.set_xlabel('x')
ax.set_ylabel('y')
ax.set_zlabel('z')

origin = np.array([0, 0, 0])

ax.quiver(*origin, 1, 0, 0, color='red', length=12, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)
ax.quiver(*origin, -1, 0, 0, color='red', length=12, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)
ax.quiver(*origin, 0, 1, 0, color='green', length=12, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)
ax.quiver(*origin, 0, -1, 0, color='green', length=12, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)
ax.quiver(*origin, 0, 0, 1, color='blue', length=12, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)
ax.quiver(*origin, 0, 0, -1, color='blue', length=12, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)

# data
tilt = 0.5
x = np.linspace(-12, 12, 10)
y = np.linspace(-12, 12, 10)
x, y = np.meshgrid(x, y)
z = tilt * x
ax.plot_surface(x, y, z, alpha=0.3, color='lightblue')

a = np.array([12, -8, 12 * tilt])
b = np.array([0, -8, 0])
bn = b / np.linalg.norm(b)

apar = np.dot(a, bn) * bn
aperp = a - apar

z = np.array([0, 0, 1])
zn = z / np.linalg.norm(z)
azpar = np.dot(a, zn) * zn
azperp = a - azpar

ax.quiver(*origin, *z, color='black', length=6, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)
ax.quiver(*origin, *azpar, color='black', length=1, arrow_length_ratio=0.15)
ax.quiver(*azpar, *azperp, color='black', length=1, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)

ax.quiver(*origin, *a, color='black', alpha=0.5, length=1, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)
ax.quiver(*origin, *b, color='black', alpha=0.5, length=1, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)
ax.quiver(*apar, *(aperp), color='black', alpha=0.5, length=1, arrow_length_ratio=0.06)

ax.text(*origin + [0, 1, 3], r'$\vec{a}_{z\parallel}$', color='black', fontsize=12)

ax.view_init(elev=20, azim=85)
plt.subplots_adjust(left=0, right=1, top=1, bottom=0)

plt.show()

Informally speaking, the "fixed projection" of a rotated vector in two dimensions is not absent, its just that it's not "visible" within the plane of rotation.

Knowing that the vector-components parallel to the rotation axis stay fixed and only the orthogonal projection changes, we conclude:

  • vâƒ—âˆ¥\vec{v}_{\parallel}vâˆ¥â€‹ is the parallel component of vâƒ—\vec{v}v onto the normalized rotation axis nâƒ—\vec{n}n. vâƒ—âˆ¥\vec{v}_{\parallel}vâˆ¥â€‹ can be computed as

    vâƒ—âˆ¥=(vâƒ—â‹…n^)â‹…n^ \vec{v}_{\parallel} = (\vec{v} \cdot \hat{n}) \cdot \hat{n}vâˆ¥â€‹=(vâ‹…n^)â‹…n^

    This is the part that never changes during rotation. Thus, the rotated vector vâƒ—â€²\vec{v}'vâ€² is the vector sum of the parallel projection and the orthogonal projection after rotation.

  • vâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{v}_{\perp}vâŠ¥â€‹ is the perpendicular component of vâƒ—\vec{v}v and lies in a two-dimensional subspace perpendicular to n^\hat{n}n^. This component vâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{v}_{\perp}vâŠ¥â€‹, also called the "rejection" of vâƒ—\vec{v}v from nâƒ—\vec{n}n ([ğŸ“–Len16, p. 29]), is obtained by subtracting the parallel component vâƒ—âˆ¥\vec{v}_{\parallel}vâˆ¥â€‹ from vâƒ—\vec{v}v:

    vâƒ—âŠ¥=vâƒ—âˆ’vâƒ—âˆ¥\vec{v}_{\perp} = \vec{v} - \vec{v}_{\parallel}vâŠ¥â€‹=vâˆ’vâˆ¥â€‹

  • While the parallel component of vâƒ—\vec{v}v stays fixed under rotation, the perpendicular component in respect to the projection changes. It can be expressed by the linear combination

    vâƒ—âŠ¥â€²=cosâ¡(Î˜)vâƒ—âŠ¥+sinâ¡(Î˜)wâƒ—\vec{v}'_{\perp} = \cos(\Theta)\vec{v}_{\perp} + \sin(\Theta)\vec{w}vâŠ¥â€²â€‹=cos(Î˜)vâŠ¥â€‹+sin(Î˜)w

    Here, the locally defined two-dimensional orthogonal basis is given by vâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{v}_{\perp}vâŠ¥â€‹ and the vector wâƒ—\vec{w}w. For the linear combination to ensure that the resulting vector vâƒ—âŠ¥â€²\vec{v}'_{\perp}vâŠ¥â€²â€‹ has the same length as vâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{v}_{\perp}vâŠ¥â€‹, the vector wâƒ—\vec{w}w must have the same magnitude as vâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{v}_{\perp}vâŠ¥â€‹ and correspond to a 90âˆ˜90^\circ90âˆ˜ counterclockwise rotation of vâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{v}_{\perp}vâŠ¥â€‹. The existence of such a vector was shown in the previous section. We can obtain the orthogonal basis by computing wâƒ—\vec{w}w via

    wâƒ—=n^Ã—vâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{w} = \hat{n} \times \vec{v}_{\perp}w=n^Ã—vâŠ¥â€‹

    Since âˆ£n^âˆ£=1|\hat{n}| = 1âˆ£n^âˆ£=1 and âˆ (n^,vâƒ—âŠ¥)=Ï€2\angle( \hat{n}, \vec{v}_{\perp}) = \frac{\pi}{2}âˆ (n^,vâŠ¥â€‹)=2Ï€â€‹, the length of wâƒ—\vec{w}w is verified with the vector cross product

    âˆ£wâƒ—âˆ£=âˆ£n^Ã—vâƒ—âŠ¥âˆ£=sinâ¡(Ï€2)â‹…âˆ£n^âˆ£â‹…âˆ£vâƒ—âŠ¥âˆ£=âˆ£vâƒ—âŠ¥âˆ£|\vec{w}| = |\hat{n} \times \vec{v}_{\perp}|= \sin(\frac{\pi}{2}) \cdot |\hat{n}| \cdot |\vec{v}_{\perp}| = |\vec{v}_{\perp}|âˆ£wâˆ£=âˆ£n^Ã—vâŠ¥â€‹âˆ£=sin(2Ï€â€‹)â‹…âˆ£n^âˆ£â‹…âˆ£vâŠ¥â€‹âˆ£=âˆ£vâŠ¥â€‹âˆ£

Deriving the Rotation Matricesâ€‹

We now derive vâƒ—â€²\vec{v}'vâ€² as the result of rotating the vector vâƒ—\vec{v}v by an angle Î˜\ThetaÎ˜ about the rotation axis nâƒ—\vec{n}n using the locally defined two-dimensional orthogonal basis, with coordinate axes vâƒ—âŠ¥\vec{v}_{\perp}vâŠ¥â€‹ and wâƒ—\vec{w}w.

vâƒ—â€²=vâƒ—âˆ¥+cosâ¡(Î˜)vâƒ—âŠ¥+sinâ¡(Î˜)wâƒ—=vâƒ—âˆ¥+cosâ¡(Î˜)(vâƒ—âˆ’vâƒ—âˆ¥)+sinâ¡(Î˜)(n^Ã—vâƒ—âŠ¥)=vâƒ—âˆ¥+cosâ¡(Î˜)(vâƒ—âˆ’(vâƒ—â‹…n^)â‹…n^)+sinâ¡(Î˜)(n^Ã—(vâƒ—âˆ’vâƒ—âˆ¥))=vâƒ—âˆ¥+cosâ¡(Î˜)(vâƒ—âˆ’(vâƒ—â‹…n^)â‹…n^)+sinâ¡(Î˜)(n^Ã—(vâƒ—âˆ’(vâƒ—â‹…n^)â‹…n^))=vâƒ—âˆ¥+cosâ¡(Î˜)(vâƒ—âˆ’(vâƒ—â‹…n^)â‹…n^)+sinâ¡(Î˜)((n^Ã—vâƒ—)âˆ’(n^Ã—((vâƒ—â‹…n^)â‹…n^)))\begin{alignat*}{3} \vec{v}' &= \vec{v}_{\parallel} + \cos(\Theta)\vec{v}_{\perp} + \sin(\Theta)\vec{w}\\ &= \vec{v}_{\parallel} + \cos(\Theta)(\vec{v} - \vec{v}_{\parallel}) + \sin(\Theta)(\hat{n} \times \vec{v}_{\perp})\\ &= \vec{v}_{\parallel} + \cos(\Theta)(\vec{v} - (\vec{v} \cdot \hat{n}) \cdot \hat{n}) + \sin(\Theta)(\hat{n} \times (\vec{v} - \vec{v}_{\parallel}))\\ &= \vec{v}_{\parallel} + \cos(\Theta)(\vec{v} - (\vec{v} \cdot \hat{n}) \cdot \hat{n}) + \sin(\Theta)(\hat{n} \times (\vec{v} - (\vec{v} \cdot \hat{n}) \cdot \hat{n}))\\ &= \vec{v}_{\parallel} + \cos(\Theta)(\vec{v} - (\vec{v} \cdot \hat{n}) \cdot \hat{n}) + \sin(\Theta)((\hat{n} \times \vec{v}) - (\hat{n} \times ((\vec{v} \cdot \hat{n}) \cdot \hat{n})))\\ \end{alignat*}vâ€²â€‹=vâˆ¥â€‹+cos(Î˜)vâŠ¥â€‹+sin(Î˜)w=vâˆ¥â€‹+cos(Î˜)(vâˆ’vâˆ¥â€‹)+sin(Î˜)(n^Ã—vâŠ¥â€‹)=vâˆ¥â€‹+cos(Î˜)(vâˆ’(vâ‹…n^)â‹…n^)+sin(Î˜)(n^Ã—(vâˆ’vâˆ¥â€‹))=vâˆ¥â€‹+cos(Î˜)(vâˆ’(vâ‹…n^)â‹…n^)+sin(Î˜)(n^Ã—(vâˆ’(vâ‹…n^)â‹…n^))=vâˆ¥â€‹+cos(Î˜)(vâˆ’(vâ‹…n^)â‹…n^)+sin(Î˜)((n^Ã—v)âˆ’(n^Ã—((vâ‹…n^)â‹…n^)))â€‹

which leads to the commonly used compact form of the Rodrigues formula:

vâƒ—â€²=vâƒ—cosâ¡(Î˜)+((vâƒ—â‹…n^)â‹…n^)(1âˆ’cosâ¡(Î˜))+(n^Ã—vâƒ—)sinâ¡(Î˜)\vec{v}' = \vec{v} \cos(\Theta) + ((\vec{v} \cdot \hat{n}) \cdot \hat{n})(1 - \cos(\Theta)) + (\hat{n} \times \vec{v})\sin(\Theta)vâ€²=vcos(Î˜)+((vâ‹…n^)â‹…n^)(1âˆ’cos(Î˜))+(n^Ã—v)sin(Î˜)

Solving componentwise, we obtain

vâƒ—âˆ¥=(vâƒ—â‹…n^)â‹…n^=((vâƒ—xn^x+vâƒ—yn^y+vâƒ—zn^z)â‹…n^x(vâƒ—xn^x+vâƒ—yn^y+vâƒ—zn^z)â‹…n^y(vâƒ—xn^x+vâƒ—yn^y+vâƒ—zn^z)â‹…n^z)Â vâƒ—âŠ¥=vâƒ—âˆ’vâƒ—âˆ¥=(vâƒ—xâˆ’(vâƒ—xn^x+vâƒ—yn^y+vâƒ—zn^z)â‹…n^xvâƒ—yâˆ’(vâƒ—xn^x+vâƒ—yn^y+vâƒ—zn^z)â‹…n^yvâƒ—zâˆ’(vâƒ—xn^x+vâƒ—yn^y+vâƒ—zn^z)â‹…n^z)Â wâƒ—=n^Ã—vâƒ—=(n^yvâƒ—zâˆ’n^zvâƒ—yn^zvâƒ—xâˆ’n^xvâƒ—zn^xvâƒ—yâˆ’n^yvâƒ—x)\begin{alignat*}{3} \vec{v}_{\parallel} &= (\vec{v} \cdot \hat{n})\cdot \hat{n} &&= \begin{pmatrix} (\vec{v}_x\hat{n}_x + \vec{v}_y\hat{n}_y + \vec{v}_z\hat{n}_z) \cdot \hat{n}_x \\ (\vec{v}_x\hat{n}_x + \vec{v}_y\hat{n}_y + \vec{v}_z\hat{n}_z) \cdot \hat{n}_y \\ (\vec{v}_x\hat{n}_x + \vec{v}_y\hat{n}_y + \vec{v}_z\hat{n}_z) \cdot \hat{n}_z \end{pmatrix}\\ \\ \ \vec{v}_{\perp} &= \vec{v} - \vec{v}_{\parallel} &&= \begin{pmatrix} \vec{v}_x - (\vec{v}_x\hat{n}_x + \vec{v}_y\hat{n}_y + \vec{v}_z\hat{n}_z) \cdot \hat{n}_x \\ \vec{v}_y - (\vec{v}_x\hat{n}_x + \vec{v}_y\hat{n}_y + \vec{v}_z\hat{n}_z) \cdot \hat{n}_y \\ \vec{v}_z - (\vec{v}_x\hat{n}_x + \vec{v}_y\hat{n}_y + \vec{v}_z\hat{n}_z) \cdot \hat{n}_z \end{pmatrix}\\ \\ \ \vec{w} &= \hat{n} \times \vec{v} &&= \begin{pmatrix} \hat{n}_y\vec{v}_z - \hat{n}_z\vec{v}_y \\ \hat{n}_z\vec{v}_x - \hat{n}_x\vec{v}_z \\ \hat{n}_x\vec{v}_y - \hat{n}_y\vec{v}_x \end{pmatrix} \end{alignat*}vâˆ¥â€‹Â vâŠ¥â€‹Â wâ€‹=(vâ‹…n^)â‹…n^=vâˆ’vâˆ¥â€‹=n^Ã—vâ€‹â€‹=â€‹(vxâ€‹n^xâ€‹+vyâ€‹n^yâ€‹+vzâ€‹n^zâ€‹)â‹…n^xâ€‹(vxâ€‹n^xâ€‹+vyâ€‹n^yâ€‹+vzâ€‹n^zâ€‹)â‹…n^yâ€‹(vxâ€‹n^xâ€‹+vyâ€‹n^yâ€‹+vzâ€‹n^zâ€‹)â‹…n^zâ€‹â€‹â€‹=â€‹vxâ€‹âˆ’(vxâ€‹n^xâ€‹+vyâ€‹n^yâ€‹+vzâ€‹n^zâ€‹)â‹…n^xâ€‹vyâ€‹âˆ’(vxâ€‹n^xâ€‹+vyâ€‹n^yâ€‹+vzâ€‹n^zâ€‹)â‹…n^yâ€‹vzâ€‹âˆ’(vxâ€‹n^xâ€‹+vyâ€‹n^yâ€‹+vzâ€‹n^zâ€‹)â‹…n^zâ€‹â€‹â€‹=â€‹n^yâ€‹vzâ€‹âˆ’n^zâ€‹vyâ€‹n^zâ€‹vxâ€‹âˆ’n^xâ€‹vzâ€‹n^xâ€‹vyâ€‹âˆ’n^yâ€‹vxâ€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹

Using a specific rotation axis, we verify that Rz(Î˜)\boldsymbol{R}_z(\Theta)Rzâ€‹(Î˜) follows directly from the Rodrigues formula. We rotate vâƒ—\vec{v}v by Î˜\ThetaÎ˜ around the zzz-axis of the orthonormal standard basis in R3\mathbb{R}^3R3.

Hence, substituting n^\hat{n}n^ by (001)\begin{pmatrix}0 \\ 0\\ 1\end{pmatrix}â€‹001â€‹â€‹ into the formula, we derive vâƒ—â€²\vec{v}'vâ€²:

vâƒ—â€²=((vâƒ—xâ‹…0+vâƒ—yâ‹…0+vâƒ—zâ‹…1)â‹…0(vâƒ—xâ‹…0+vâƒ—yâ‹…0+vâƒ—zâ‹…1)â‹…0(vâƒ—xâ‹…0+vâƒ—yâ‹…0+vâƒ—zâ‹…1)â‹…1)+cosâ¡(Î˜)(vâƒ—xâˆ’(vâƒ—xâ‹…0+vâƒ—yâ‹…0+vâƒ—zâ‹…1)â‹…0vâƒ—yâˆ’(vâƒ—xâ‹…0+vâƒ—yâ‹…0+vâƒ—zâ‹…1)â‹…0vâƒ—zâˆ’(vâƒ—xâ‹…0+vâƒ—yâ‹…0+vâƒ—zâ‹…1)â‹…1)+sinâ¡(Î˜)(0â‹…vâƒ—zâˆ’1â‹…vâƒ—y1â‹…vâƒ—xâˆ’0â‹…vâƒ—z0â‹…vâƒ—yâˆ’0â‹…vâƒ—x)Â =(00vâƒ—z)+cosâ¡(Î˜)(vâƒ—xvâƒ—y0)+sinâ¡(Î˜)(âˆ’vâƒ—yvâƒ—x0)Â =(cosâ¡(Î˜)vâƒ—xâˆ’sinâ¡(Î˜)vâƒ—ycos␀â¡(Î˜)vâƒ—y+sinâ¡(Î˜)vâƒ—xvâƒ—z)\begin{alignat*}{3} \vec{v}' &= \begin{pmatrix} (\vec{v}_x \cdot 0 + \vec{v}_y \cdot 0 + \vec{v}_z \cdot 1) \cdot 0 \\ (\vec{v}_x \cdot 0 + \vec{v}_y \cdot 0 + \vec{v}_z \cdot 1) \cdot 0 \\ (\vec{v}_x \cdot 0 + \vec{v}_y \cdot 0 + \vec{v}_z \cdot 1) \cdot 1 \end{pmatrix} + \cos(\Theta) \begin{pmatrix} \vec{v}_x - (\vec{v}_x \cdot 0 + \vec{v}_y\cdot 0 + \vec{v}_z\cdot 1) \cdot 0 \\ \vec{v}_y - (\vec{v}_x\cdot 0 + \vec{v}_y\cdot 0 + \vec{v}_z\cdot 1) \cdot 0 \\ \vec{v}_z - (\vec{v}_x\cdot 0 + \vec{v}_y\cdot 0 + \vec{v}_z\cdot 1) \cdot 1 \end{pmatrix} + \sin(\Theta)\begin{pmatrix} 0 \cdot \vec{v}_z - 1 \cdot \vec{v}_y \\ 1\cdot\vec{v}_x - 0\cdot\vec{v}_z \\ 0\cdot\vec{v}_y - 0\cdot\vec{v}_x \end{pmatrix}\\ \\ \ &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ \vec{v}_z \end{pmatrix} + \cos(\Theta) \begin{pmatrix} \vec{v}_x \\ \vec{v}_y \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} + \sin(\Theta)\begin{pmatrix} - \vec{v}_y \\ \vec{v}_x \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}\\ \\ \ &= \begin{pmatrix} \cos(\Theta) \vec{v}_x - \sin(\Theta)\vec{v}_y \\ \cos(\Theta) \vec{v}_y + \sin(\Theta)\vec{v}_x \\ \vec{v}_z \end{pmatrix} \end{alignat*}vâ€²Â Â â€‹=â€‹(vxâ€‹â‹…0+vyâ€‹â‹…0+vzâ€‹â‹…1)â‹…0(vxâ€‹â‹…0+vyâ€‹â‹…0+vzâ€‹â‹…1)â‹…0(vxâ€‹â‹…0+vyâ€‹â‹…0+vzâ€‹â‹…1)â‹…1â€‹â€‹+cos(Î˜)â€‹vxâ€‹âˆ’(vxâ€‹â‹…0+vyâ€‹â‹…0+vzâ€‹â‹…1)â‹…0vyâ€‹âˆ’(vxâ€‹â‹…0+vyâ€‹â‹…0+vzâ€‹â‹…1)â‹…0vzâ€‹âˆ’(vxâ€‹â‹…0+vyâ€‹â‹…0+vzâ€‹â‹…1)â‹…1â€‹â€‹+sin(Î˜)â€‹0â‹…vzâ€‹âˆ’1â‹…vyâ€‹1â‹…vxâ€‹âˆ’0â‹…vzâ€‹0â‹…vyâ€‹âˆ’0â‹…vxâ€‹â€‹â€‹=â€‹00vzâ€‹â€‹â€‹+cos(Î˜)â€‹vxâ€‹vyâ€‹0â€‹â€‹+sin(Î˜)â€‹âˆ’vyâ€‹vxâ€‹0â€‹â€‹=â€‹cos(Î˜)vxâ€‹âˆ’sin(Î˜)vyâ€‹cos(Î˜)vyâ€‹+sin(Î˜)vxâ€‹vzâ€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹

which corresponds to the matrix-vector product of Rz(Î˜)\boldsymbol{R}_z(\Theta)Rzâ€‹(Î˜) and vâƒ—\vec{v}v

vâƒ—â€²=(cosâ¡(Î˜)vâƒ—xâˆ’sinâ¡(Î˜)vâƒ—ycosâ¡(Î˜)vâƒ—y+sinâ¡(Î˜)vâƒ—xvâƒ—z)Â =(cosâ¡(Î˜)vâƒ—xâˆ’sinâ¡(Î˜)vâƒ—ysinâ¡(Î˜)vâƒ—x+cosâ¡(Î˜)vâƒ—yvâƒ—z)Â =(cosâ¡(Î˜)âˆ’sinâ¡(Î˜)0sinâ¡(Î˜)cosâ¡(Î˜)0001)â‹…(vâƒ—xvâƒ—yvâƒ—z)Â =Rz(Î˜)vâƒ—\begin{alignat*}{3} \vec{v}' &= \begin{pmatrix} \cos(\Theta) \vec{v}_x - \sin(\Theta)\vec{v}_y \\ \cos(\Theta) \vec{v}_y + \sin(\Theta)\vec{v}_x \\ \vec{v}_z \end{pmatrix} \\ \\ \ &= \begin{pmatrix} \cos(\Theta) \vec{v}_x - \sin(\Theta)\vec{v}_y \\ \sin(\Theta)\vec{v}_x + \cos(\Theta) \vec{v}_y \\ \vec{v}_z \end{pmatrix}\\ \\ \ &= \begin{pmatrix} \cos(\Theta) & -\sin(\Theta) & 0 \\ \sin(\Theta) & \cos(\Theta) & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} \vec{v}_x \\ \vec{v}_y \\ \vec{v}_z \end{pmatrix}\\ \\ \ &= \boldsymbol{R}_z(\Theta) \vec{v} \end{alignat*}vâ€²Â Â Â â€‹=â€‹cos(Î˜)vxâ€‹âˆ’sin(Î˜)vyâ€‹cos(Î˜)vyâ€‹+sin(Î˜)vxâ€‹vzâ€‹â€‹â€‹=â€‹cos(Î˜)vxâ€‹âˆ’sin(Î˜)vyâ€‹sin(Î˜)vxâ€‹+cos(Î˜)vyâ€‹vzâ€‹â€‹â€‹=â€‹cos(Î˜)sin(Î˜)0â€‹âˆ’sin(Î˜)cos(Î˜)0â€‹001â€‹â€‹â‹…â€‹vxâ€‹vyâ€‹vzâ€‹â€‹â€‹=Rzâ€‹(Î˜)vâ€‹

This confirms that the rotation matrix Rz(Î˜)\boldsymbol{R}_z(\Theta)Rzâ€‹(Î˜) follows directly from Rodrigues' rotation formula.

Similar computations apply to Rx(Î˜)\boldsymbol{R}_x(\Theta)Rxâ€‹(Î˜) and Ry(Î˜)\boldsymbol{R}_y(\Theta)Ryâ€‹(Î˜).

Rodriguesâ€™ Rotation Formula in Matrix Formâ€‹

The following form of Rodriguesâ€™ rotation formula:

vâƒ—â€²=vâƒ—cosâ¡(Î˜)+((vâƒ—â‹…n^)â‹…n^)(1âˆ’cosâ¡(Î˜))+(n^Ã—vâƒ—)sinâ¡(Î˜)\vec{v}' = \vec{v} \cos(\Theta) + ((\vec{v} \cdot \hat{n}) \cdot \hat{n})(1 - \cos(\Theta)) + (\hat{n} \times \vec{v})\sin(\Theta)vâ€²=vcos(Î˜)+((vâ‹…n^)â‹…n^)(1âˆ’cos(Î˜))+(n^Ã—v)sin(Î˜)

is expanded into matrix form in the following steps.

1. Term vâƒ—cosâ¡(Î˜)\vec{v} \cos(\Theta)vcos(Î˜): Identity componentâ€‹

This term is equivalent to the product of a scaled identity matrix and the vector vâƒ—\vec{v}v.

(cosâ¡Î˜000cosâ¡Î˜000cosâ¡Î˜)vâƒ—\begin{pmatrix} \cos \Theta & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & \cos \Theta & 0 \\ 0 & 0& \cos \Theta \end{pmatrix} \vec{v}â€‹cosÎ˜00â€‹0cosÎ˜0â€‹00cosÎ˜â€‹â€‹v

We expand (vâƒ—â‹…n^)n^(\vec{v} \cdot \hat{n}) \hat{n}(vâ‹…n^)n^ explicitly into component form:

This yields the following matrix representation:

(n^x2n^xn^yn^xn^zn^xn^yn^y2n^yn^zn^xn^zn^yn^zn^z2)(vâƒ—xvâƒ—yvâƒ—z)\begin{alignat*}{3} \begin{pmatrix} \hat{n}^2_x & \hat{n}_x\hat{n}_y & \hat{n}_x\hat{n}_z\\ \hat{n}_x\hat{n}_y & \hat{n}^2_y & \hat{n}_y\hat{n}_z\\ \hat{n}_x\hat{n}_z & \hat{n}_y\hat{n}_z & \hat{n}^2_z \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \vec{v}_x\\ \vec{v}_y\\ \vec{v}_z \end{pmatrix} \end{alignat*}â€‹n^x2â€‹n^xâ€‹n^yâ€‹n^xâ€‹n^zâ€‹â€‹n^xâ€‹n^yâ€‹n^y2â€‹n^yâ€‹n^zâ€‹â€‹n^xâ€‹n^zâ€‹n^yâ€‹n^zâ€‹n^z2â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹vxâ€‹vyâ€‹vzâ€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹

This matrix product is the outer product of n^\hat{n}n^ with itself and vâƒ—\vec{v}v:

n^n^Tvâƒ—\hat{n} \hat{n}^T \vec{v}n^n^Tv

with nm,vmn_m, v_mnmâ€‹,vmâ€‹ being the 3Ã—13 \times 13Ã—1 matrix representation (i.e., column vector form) of n^\hat{n}n^ and vâƒ—\vec{v}v, respectively:

[(n^xn^yn^z)(n^xn^yn^z)](vâƒ—xvâƒ—yvâƒ—z)\begin{bmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} \hat{n}_x \\ \hat{n}_y \\ \hat{n}_z \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \hat{n}_x & \hat{n}_y & \hat{n}_z \end{pmatrix} \end{bmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \vec{v}_x \\ \vec{v}_y \\ \vec{v}_z \end{pmatrix}â€‹â€‹n^xâ€‹n^yâ€‹n^zâ€‹â€‹â€‹(n^xâ€‹â€‹n^yâ€‹â€‹n^zâ€‹â€‹)â€‹â€‹â€‹vxâ€‹vyâ€‹vzâ€‹â€‹â€‹

This yields the following matrix expression:

(n^x2n^xn^yn^xn^zn^xn^yn^y2n^yn^zn^xn^zn^yn^zn^z2)(1âˆ’cosâ¡Î˜)vâƒ—\begin{alignat*}{3} \begin{pmatrix} \hat{n}^2_x & \hat{n}_x\hat{n}_y & \hat{n}_x\hat{n}_z\\ \hat{n}_x\hat{n}_y & \hat{n}^2_y & \hat{n}_y\hat{n}_z\\ \hat{n}_x\hat{n}_z & \hat{n}_y\hat{n}_z & \hat{n}^2_z \end{pmatrix}(1 - \cos \Theta)\vec{v} \end{alignat*}â€‹n^x2â€‹n^xâ€‹n^yâ€‹n^xâ€‹n^zâ€‹â€‹n^xâ€‹n^yâ€‹n^y2â€‹n^yâ€‹n^zâ€‹â€‹n^xâ€‹n^zâ€‹n^yâ€‹n^zâ€‹n^z2â€‹â€‹â€‹(1âˆ’cos␀Î˜)vâ€‹

3. Term (n^Ã—vâƒ—)sinâ¡(Î˜)(\hat{n} \times \vec{v})\sin(\Theta)(n^Ã—v)sin(Î˜): Skew componentâ€‹

This can be expressed using the skew matrix:

(0âˆ’n^zn^yn^z0âˆ’n^xâˆ’n^yn^x0)(sinâ¡Î˜)vâƒ—\begin{pmatrix} 0 & -\hat{n}_z & \hat{n}_y \\ \hat{n}_z & 0 & -\hat{n}_x \\ -\hat{n}_y & \hat{n}_x & 0 \end{pmatrix} (\sin \Theta)\vec{v}â€‹0n^zâ€‹âˆ’n^yâ€‹â€‹âˆ’n^zâ€‹0n^xâ€‹â€‹n^yâ€‹âˆ’n^xâ€‹0â€‹â€‹(sinÎ˜)v

4. Final Matrix form of the Rodrigues formulaâ€‹

Combining all three components, the final matrix form of the rotation matrix is:

R(Î¸,n^)=(cosâ¡Î˜000cosâ¡Î˜000cosâ¡Î˜)+(n^x2n^xn^yn^xn^zn^xn^yn^y2n^yn^zn^xn^zn^yn^zn^z2)(1âˆ’cosâ¡Î˜)+(0âˆ’n^zn^yn^z0âˆ’n^xâˆ’n^yn^x0)(sinâ¡Î˜)=(cosâ¡Î˜+n^x2(1âˆ’cosâ¡Î˜)n^xn^y(1âˆ’cosâ¡Î˜)âˆ’n^zsinâ¡Î˜n^xn^z(1âˆ’cosâ¡Î˜)+n^ysinâ¡Î˜n^xn^y(1âˆ’cosâ¡Î˜)+n^zsinâ¡Î˜cosâ¡Î˜+n^y2(1âˆ’cosâ¡Î˜)n^yn^z(1âˆ’cosâ¡Î˜)âˆ’n^xsinâ¡Î˜n^xn^z(1âˆ’cosâ¡Î˜)âˆ’n^ysinâ¡Î˜n^yn^z(1âˆ’cosâ¡Î˜)+n^xsinâ¡Î˜cosâ¡Î˜+n^z2(1âˆ’cosâ¡Î˜))\begin{alignat*}{3} \boldsymbol{R}(\theta, \hat{n}) &= \begin{pmatrix} \cos \Theta & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & \cos \Theta & 0 \\ 0 & 0& \cos \Theta \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} \hat{n}^2_x & \hat{n}_x\hat{n}_y & \hat{n}_x\hat{n}_z\\ \hat{n}_x\hat{n}_y & \hat{n}^2_y & \hat{n}_y\hat{n}_z\\ \hat{n}_x\hat{n}_z & \hat{n}_y\hat{n}_z & \hat{n}^2_z \end{pmatrix}(1 - \cos \Theta) + \begin{pmatrix} 0 & -\hat{n}_z & \hat{n}_y \\ \hat{n}_z & 0 & -\hat{n}_x \\ -\hat{n}_y & \hat{n}_x & 0 \end{pmatrix} (\sin \Theta)\\ & \qquad\\ & = \begin{pmatrix} \cos \Theta + \hat{n}^2_x (1 - \cos \Theta) & \hat{n}_x\hat{n}_y (1 - \cos \Theta) -\hat{n}_z \sin \Theta & \hat{n}_x\hat{n}_z (1 - \cos \Theta) + \hat{n}_y \sin \Theta\\ \hat{n}_x\hat{n}_y (1 - \cos \Theta) + \hat{n}_z \sin \Theta & \cos \Theta + \hat{n}^2_y (1 - \cos \Theta) & \hat{n}_y\hat{n}_z (1 - \cos \Theta) -\hat{n}_x \sin \Theta \\ \hat{n}_x\hat{n}_z (1 - \cos \Theta) -\hat{n}_y \sin \Theta & \hat{n}_y\hat{n}_z (1 - \cos \Theta) + \hat{n}_x \sin \Theta & \cos \Theta + \hat{n}^2_z (1 - \cos \Theta) \end{pmatrix} \end{alignat*}R(Î¸,n^)â€‹=â€‹cosÎ˜00â€‹0cosÎ˜0â€‹00cosÎ˜â€‹â€‹+â€‹n^x2â€‹n^xâ€‹n^yâ€‹n^xâ€‹n^zâ€‹â€‹n^xâ€‹n^yâ€‹n^y2â€‹n^yâ€‹n^zâ€‹â€‹n^xâ€‹n^zâ€‹n^yâ€‹n^zâ€‹n^z2â€‹â€‹â€‹(1âˆ’cosÎ˜)+â€‹0n^zâ€‹âˆ’n^yâ€‹â€‹âˆ’n^zâ€‹0n^xâ€‹â€‹n^yâ€‹âˆ’n^xâ€‹0â€‹â€‹(sinÎ˜)=â€‹cosÎ˜+n^x2â€‹(1âˆ’cosÎ˜)n^xâ€‹n^yâ€‹(1âˆ’cosÎ˜)+n^zâ€‹sinÎ˜n^xâ€‹n^zâ€‹(1âˆ’cosÎ˜)âˆ’n^yâ€‹sinÎ˜â€‹n^xâ€‹n^yâ€‹(1âˆ’cosÎ˜)âˆ’n^zâ€‹sinÎ˜cosÎ˜+n^y2â€‹(1âˆ’cosÎ˜)n^yâ€‹n^zâ€‹(1âˆ’cosÎ˜)+n^xâ€‹sinÎ˜â€‹n^xâ€‹n^zâ€‹(1âˆ’cosÎ˜)+n^yâ€‹sinÎ˜n^yâ€‹n^zâ€‹(1âˆ’cosÎ˜)âˆ’n^xâ€‹sinÎ˜cosÎ˜+n^z2â€‹(1âˆ’cosÎ˜)â€‹â€‹â€‹

By factoring vâƒ—\vec{v}v in each term of the expansion, we arrive at a single matrix R(Î˜,n^)\boldsymbol{R}(\Theta, \hat{n})R(Î˜,n^), which is a composition of a scaled identity, a projection along the rotation axis, and a skew transformation representing the cross product.

Hence, the rotation can be written in one step as

vâƒ—â€²=R(Î˜,n^)vâƒ—\vec{v}' = \boldsymbol{R}(\Theta, \hat{n}) \vec{v}vâ€²=R(Î˜,n^)v
Application: Rodrigues rotation matrix with GLM in C++

When the rotation axis nâƒ—\vec{n}n and the rotation angle Î˜\ThetaÎ˜ are known, a corresponding rotation matrix can be conveniently implemented as a function.

The following C++ function returns a glm::mat3 representing a rotation around an arbitrary axis, using GLM (OpenGL Mathematics)7:

mat3 Transform::rotate(const float degrees, const vec3& axis) {

    float theta = radians(degrees);

    vec3 n = normalize(axis);

    float cos_theta = cos(theta);
    float sin_theta = sin(theta);
    float t = 1.0f - cos_theta;

    return mat3(
        cos_theta + n.x * n.x * t,
        n.x * n.y * t + n.z * sin_theta,
        n.x * n.z * t - n.y * sin_theta,

        n.x * n.y * t - n.z * sin_theta,
        cos_theta + n.y * n.y * t,
        n.y*n.z * t + n.x * sin_theta,

        n.x * n.z * t + n.y * sin_theta,
        n.y * n.z * t - n.x * sin_theta,
        cos_theta + n.z * n.z * t
    );
}

Given a vector glm::vec3 v, its rotation around the specified axis by 45âˆ˜45^\circ45âˆ˜ can be computed as follows:

vec3 vr = rotate(45.0f, axis) * v;

Application: Scene Graphs and Active Object Transformationsâ€‹

In video games and animations, set pieces typically consist of a large number of objects, each requiring individual transformations. Since some of these objects share parent-child-relationships with others (e.g. aggregates), multiple coordinate systems may be involved. Consequently, transformations must be computed with proper consideration of the corresponding (embedded) coordinate systems.

To keep track of these interdependent and independent objects, game and animation engines use hierarchical data structures that serve different puposes, such as discarding objects outside of the view frustum to reduce the cost of culling operations. Depending on the use case, the applied data structure is ultimately an implementation detail ([ğŸ“–Jas19, p. 693]).

Figure 9 shows a scene graph as a simplified representation of an in-game scene from the game Clair Obscur: Expedition 338 (Figure 8). The scene depicts a battle sequence in which the camera moves between fixed positions, based on user interaction and decisions made by the game engine while computing NPC AI.

Figure 8 Reaper Cultist NPCs (right) from 'Clair Obscur: Expedition 33' have 3 orbs rotating around its upper torso, serving as buffs.

In the battle scenes depicted in the screenshot, enemies of the type Reaper Cultist have orbs rotating around their upper torso. The scene graph shown in Figure 9 illustrates a simplified model of these NPCs embedded in the scene, including their orbs, which are represented as individual objects. The handling of multiple (geometric) objects sharing the same type is usually an implementation detail and can also be realized using geometric instances ([ğŸ“–RTR, p. 796], [ğŸ“–PF05, p. 47]).

Figure 9 Simplified scene graph for the depicted battle scene in Clair Obscur.

As illustrated by the scene graph, a floating orb is positioned relative to the head of the npc, which in turn is positioned relative to the EnemyNPC1_11â€‹, whose position is defined in world coordinates.

We now abstract the geometric context in Figure 10 to demonstrate how Rodrigues rotation can be applied.

The animation shows a single vector in world coordinates representing EnemyNPC1_11â€‹, along with three spheres arranged around it. The origin of a sphere's local coordinate system is thus defined by the vector's endpoint - i.e. the NPCs head.

Implementing engines must ensure that all vectors are interpreted in the correct context: Since relative positions are provided as points in the coordinate system, it is necessary to derive direction vectors from these positions - typically by computing differences between them and some sort of reference points. For this purpose, any point on the rotation axis can serve as a reference point, because orthogonal projections remain unchanged even if the magnitude of the parallel component varies - as long as the direction remains constant. This is due to the fact that orthogonal and parallel vector components are treated independently in the projection process, as shown in the previous sections.

In these cases, we typically arrive at a composite transformation of the form

vâƒ—World=T1â‹…T2â‹…â€¦â‹…Tnâ‹…R(Î˜,n^)â‹…vâƒ—Object\vec{v}_{World} = \boldsymbol{T}_{1} \cdot \boldsymbol{T}_{2} \cdot \ldots \cdot \boldsymbol{T}_{n} \cdot \boldsymbol{R}(\Theta, \hat{n}) \cdot \vec{v}_{Object}vWorldâ€‹=T1â€‹â‹…T2â€‹â‹…â€¦â‹…Tnâ€‹â‹…R(Î˜,n^)â‹…vObjectâ€‹

where the translation matrices Ti\boldsymbol{T}_iTiâ€‹ successively map each object into the coordinate system of its parent, with transformations applied from right to left ([ğŸ“–LGK23, p. 149 ff.]).

  • Dynamic
  • Stationary
Figure 10 Visualization of 3 objects rotating around a moving npc. Simplified scene graph for the depicted battle scene in Clair Obscur.
Plot-Code (Python)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from matplotlib import rcParams
import numpy as np
import math
import random
from matplotlib.animation import FuncAnimation
from IPython.display import HTML
rcParams['animation.embed_limit'] = 50_000_000  # 50 MB

def rodrigues(theta, v, n):
    vn = v / np.linalg.norm(v)
    nn = n / np.linalg.norm(n)
    vpar = np.dot(nn, v) * nn
    vperp = v - vpar

    return vpar + (np.cos(theta) * (vperp)) + (np.sin(theta) * np.cross(nn, v))

fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10, 8))
ax = fig.add_subplot(projection='3d')
plt.subplots_adjust(left=0, right=1, top=1, bottom=0)


npc = np.array([3, 3, 2]) # point coordinates of npc in world
v = np.array([0, 0, 2])   # direction vector of the npc
o1 = np.array([-1, 1, 1])  # orb 1
o2 = np.array([1, 1.5, -1])  # orb2
o3 = np.array([0.5, 3, 0]) # orb 3

theta = 0
end = 360
steps = 2


def init():
    ax.set_xlim([0, 6])
    ax.set_ylim([0, 6])
    ax.set_zlim([0, 6])

    ax.set_xlabel('x')
    ax.set_ylabel('y')
    ax.set_zlabel('z')

    ax.quiver(0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0, color='grey', length=6, arrow_length_ratio=0.04)
    ax.quiver(0, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, color='grey', length=6, arrow_length_ratio=0.04)
    ax.quiver(0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, color='grey', length=6, arrow_length_ratio=0.04)

    ax.view_init(elev=10, azim=-45)


def update(theta):
    global v
    ax.cla()
    init()
    rad = theta* (math.pi/180)

    sindelta = np.sin(rad*2)
    cosdelta = np.cos(rad*2)

    #npc vector
    origin = np.array([npc[0] + cosdelta/5, npc[1] + sindelta/5, npc[2] + sindelta/1.2]);
    ax.quiver(*origin, *v, color='black', linewidth=4,  arrow_length_ratio=0.05)

    ep1 = rodrigues(rad, [o1[0], o1[1], o1[2] + sindelta/1.2], v)
    ep2 = rodrigues(rad, [o2[0] - cosdelta, o2[1] - sindelta, o2[2] + sindelta/1.25], v)
    ep3 = rodrigues(rad, [o3[0], o3[1], o3[2] + sindelta/1.3], v)

    ax.quiver(*origin + v, *(ep1), color='cyan', linewidth=1,  arrow_length_ratio=0.05)
    ax.quiver(*origin + v, *(ep2), color='cyan', linewidth=1,  arrow_length_ratio=0.05)
    ax.quiver(*origin + v, *(ep3), color='cyan', linewidth=1,  arrow_length_ratio=0.05)


    ax.scatter(*(ep1 + origin + v), color='red', s=100)
    ax.scatter(*(ep2 + origin + v), color='green', s=100)
    ax.scatter(*(ep3 + origin + v), color='blue', s=100)

    theta += steps

ani = FuncAnimation(fig, update, frames=list(range(0, end, steps)), interval=30)
ani.save(
    #path
    writer="pillow",
    fps=30
)


Figure 11 Visualization of 3 objects rotating around a moving npc. Simplified scene graph for the depicted battle scene in Clair Obscur.
Plot-Code (Python)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from matplotlib import rcParams
import numpy as np
import math
import random
from matplotlib.animation import FuncAnimation
from IPython.display import HTML

rcParams['animation.embed_limit'] = 50_000_000  # 50 MB

def rodrigues(theta, v, n):
    vn = v / np.linalg.norm(v)
    nn = n / np.linalg.norm(n)
    vpar = np.dot(nn, v) * nn
    vperp = v - vpar

    return vpar + (np.cos(theta) * (vperp)) + (np.sin(theta) * np.cross(nn, v))

fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10, 8))
ax = fig.add_subplot(projection='3d')
plt.subplots_adjust(left=0, right=1, top=1, bottom=0)


npc = np.array([3, 3, 2]) # point coordinates of npc in world
v = np.array([0, 0, 2])   # direction vector of the npc
o1 = np.array([-1, 1, 1])  # orb 1
o2 = np.array([1, 1.5, -1])  # orb2
o3 = np.array([0.5, 3, 0]) # orb 3

theta = 0
end = 360
steps = 2


def init():
    ax.set_xlim([0, 6])
    ax.set_ylim([0, 6])
    ax.set_zlim([0, 6])

    ax.set_xlabel('x')
    ax.set_ylabel('y')
    ax.set_zlabel('z')

    ax.quiver(0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0, color='grey', length=6, arrow_length_ratio=0.04)
    ax.quiver(0, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, color='grey', length=6, arrow_length_ratio=0.04)
    ax.quiver(0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, color='grey', length=6, arrow_length_ratio=0.04)

    ax.view_init(elev=10, azim=-45)


def update(theta):
    global v
    ax.cla()
    init()
    rad = theta* (math.pi/180)

    sindelta = np.sin(rad*2)
    cosdelta = np.cos(rad*2)

    #npc vector
    origin = npc
    ax.quiver(*origin, *v, color='black', linewidth=4,  arrow_length_ratio=0.05)

    ep1 = rodrigues(rad, [o1[0], o1[1], o1[2] + sindelta/1.2], v)
    ep2 = rodrigues(rad, [o2[0] - cosdelta, o2[1] - sindelta, o2[2] + sindelta/1.25], v)
    ep3 = rodrigues(rad, [o3[0], o3[1], o3[2] + sindelta/1.3], v)

    ax.quiver(*origin + v, *(ep1), color='cyan', linewidth=1,  arrow_length_ratio=0.05)
    ax.quiver(*origin + v, *(ep2), color='cyan', linewidth=1,  arrow_length_ratio=0.05)
    ax.quiver(*origin + v, *(ep3), color='cyan', linewidth=1,  arrow_length_ratio=0.05)


    ax.scatter(*(ep1 + origin + v), color='red', s=100)
    ax.scatter(*(ep2 + origin + v), color='green', s=100)
    ax.scatter(*(ep3 + origin + v), color='blue', s=100)

    theta += steps

ani = FuncAnimation(fig, update, frames=list(range(0, end, steps)), interval=30)
ani.save(
    #path
    writer="pillow",
    fps=30
)


The example above has been deliberately simplified for demonstration purposes, and it should be noted that, in a scene where hundreds of thousands of vertices have to undergo rotation, reducing the computational complexity of operations and improving numerical stability of floating-point computations might be equally important - especially in real-time rendering contexts.
In addition to the Rodrigues formula, Euler angles and quaternions ([ğŸ“–Ham40]) can be considered for applying rotations in three-dimensional space. Discussions of their respective advantages and limitations are provided by Shoemaker ([ğŸ“–Sho85]), Hughes et al. ([ğŸ“–HDMS+14]), and Dunn and Parberry ([ğŸ“–DP11]).
